name: MAAT - Museum of Art, Architecture and Technology
tagline: Striking contemporary museum on the Tagus riverfront exploring art, architecture and technology

description.short: MAAT is Lisbon's innovative contemporary museum dedicated to art, architecture, and technology, housed in a stunning waterfront building designed by Amanda Levete. Opened in 2016 in Belém, it combines cutting-edge exhibitions with a historic power station and riverside public spaces.
description.full: The Museum of Art, Architecture and Technology (MAAT) opened in October 2016 as an ambitious international cultural institution on Lisbon's Belém waterfront. Created by EDP Foundation as part of their long-standing cultural patronage, MAAT aims to spark critical discourse and creative practice about our historical present and responsible commitment to the future. The museum campus comprises three distinctive spaces: the striking contemporary MAAT Gallery building designed by British architect Amanda Levete's firm AL_A, the historic Central Tejo power station (built 1908-1940s, converted to MAAT Central), and MAAT Garden - a beautifully landscaped 225-meter riverside park by Lebanese architect Vladimir Djurovic connecting everything. The MAAT Gallery building is an architectural masterpiece that has become one of Lisbon's most recognizable modern landmarks. Its low-slung design features a distinctive undulating roof covered in 15,000 three-dimensional white tiles that catch and reflect the Tagus River's light. The building merges with the landscape - visitors can walk on, under, and through it, with the roof accessible as a riverside promenade offering stunning city and river views. Inside, 3,000 square meters of exhibition space flows organically through volumes of radically different scales, including the unusual elliptical Oval Gallery. MAAT Central, the converted Central Tejo power station, preserves Portugal's industrial heritage while housing permanent exhibitions about electricity's history (The Electricity Factory), plus rotating contemporary exhibitions. The historic brick-clad iron structure with its massive turbines and machinery creates a dramatic contrast to the sleek modern gallery. MAAT presents an ambitious program of temporary exhibitions featuring international contemporary artists, architects, and technologists, along with public programs, workshops, performances, and events. The museum's mission goes beyond traditional museum functions - it seeks to question and celebrate how we imagine (with art), inhabit (with architecture), and create (with technology) the world, fostering critical thinking about our relationship with the planetary ecosystem.
description.history: The Central Tejo power station was constructed between 1908 and the 1940s, belonging to Companhias Reunidas de Gás e Eletricidade (CRGE). It supplied electricity to Lisbon from 1909 to 1954, with limited service until the 1970s. Listed as a building of public interest in 1986, it opened as the Museum of Electricity in 1990, underwent restoration, and reopened in 2006. In 2016, EDP Foundation transformed the site into MAAT, adding Amanda Levete's contemporary building to create an integrated art, architecture, and technology museum campus.
description.significance: MAAT represents one of Europe's most innovative contemporary museum projects, combining industrial heritage preservation with cutting-edge contemporary architecture. Amanda Levete's building is internationally recognized for its architectural excellence and sensitive integration with the historic waterfront. The museum plays a vital role in Lisbon's cultural landscape, bringing world-class contemporary art, architecture, and technology exhibitions to Portugal while contributing to the revitalization of the Belém waterfront area.

directions.general: Located on the Tagus River waterfront in Belém district, between Jerónimos Monastery and 25 de Abril Bridge
directions.fromCruisePort: 7km west - take Tram 15E from Praça do Comércio (35 minutes) or taxi/Uber (15 minutes). Scenic riverside location.
directions.publicTransport: Tram 15E from Praça do Comércio to Altinho stop (5-minute walk from museum). Trains from Cais do Sodré to Belém station (10-minute walk). Buses 728, 714, 727, 729, 751. Free shuttle from Cais do Sodré weekends.
directions.parking: Free public parking 500m from museum. Bicycle parking available at entrance.

admissionPrices.notes: Portuguese residents: Adults €11, Students €8, Seniors 65+/Unemployed €9. Non-residents: Adults €15, Students €8. Children 0-12 free. Free first Sunday of month 10:00-13:00 (Portuguese residents only). MAAT Friends membership available. Students require valid ID.

visitingInformation.averageVisitDuration: 2-3 hours for full museum and grounds
visitingInformation.bestTimeToVisit: Weekday mornings less crowded. Late afternoon for beautiful light on the building and river views. Sunset from the rooftop walkway is spectacular.
visitingInformation.adviceForVisitors: Don't miss walking on the undulating rooftop for stunning Tagus River and Belém views. Visit both the modern MAAT Gallery and historic Central Tejo power station. Allow time to explore MAAT Garden along the riverfront. The riverside promenade extends to nearby attractions. Photography encouraged. Combine with other Belém attractions (Jerónimos, Belém Tower) for full-day itinerary. MAAT Café & Kitchen offers dining with river views.

cruisePassengerInfo.timeNeededFromPort: Half day minimum - 4-5 hours including travel and Belém exploration
cruisePassengerInfo.accessibility: Good - Tram 15E provides direct access. Museum fully wheelchair accessible with elevators and ramps. Moderate distance from port requires dedicated time.
tips: Perfect for contemporary art and architecture enthusiasts
Combine with Belém's UNESCO World Heritage sites

Free rooftop access even without museum ticket
MAAT Central (power station) shows Portugal's industrial heritage
Beautiful riverside garden perfect for relaxing
MAAT Café offers lunch with stunning river views
Architecture itself is worth the visit - Amanda Levete design
Visit Pastéis de Belém bakery (15-minute walk) for famous custard tarts
Allow 4-5 hours for full Belém district experience
First Sunday of month free for Portuguese residents (10:00-13:00)
Excellent museum shop with Portuguese design products

highlights: Stunning contemporary building by Amanda Levete/AL_A
15,000 white ceramic tiles creating wave-like roof
Accessible rooftop walkway with panoramic Tagus River views
3,000 m² exhibition space with unique Oval Gallery

accessibility.mobilityNotes: Fully wheelchair accessible. Elevators and ramps throughout both buildings. Wheelchair accessible restrooms. Two wheelchairs available on request at ticket office. Adapted for visitors with reduced mobility.
